newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: FORECAST-Economists edge up S.Africa CPI forecasts.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-Economists edge up S.Africa CPI forecasts.

text.p: Consumer inflation was expected to peak at a slightly higher rate than initially anticipated after the release of worse-than-expected September data on Wednesday, economists said.
Central Statistical Service data released on Wednesday showed the consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.0 percent month-on-month and 8.4 percent year-on-year in September.
A Reuters poll of economists forecast a consensus 0.7 percent month-on-month and 8.1 percent year-on-year rise.

"It is a bad number but not too serious. We were expecting a 9.0 percent peak (for the year), but now we are expecting 9.2 or 9.3 percent in November/December," Nedcor chief economist Dennis Dykes said.
Standard Bank Economics Division also said it was lifting its forecast to 9.0 percent from the 8.7 percent it originally expected.
"The higher-than-expected number does not make much difference to our 1996 year average forecast, which rises slightly from 7.2 percent to 7.3 percent," it said.
"However, the peak for the year is now expected to reach 9.o percent," it added.
ING Barings economist Hania Farhan said she expected a year end rate of 9.5 percent, primarily as a result of rising food prices.
The food component of the overall CPI increased 1.9 percent in September from August, the main reason for the overall 1.0 percent rise.

"The food price index is expected to continue to increase as the availability of its components changes with the season," Farhan said, "and this will account for most of the monthly CPI increases for the rest of the year."
Farhan said the transport and fuel and power components of the index would also begin to rise in October as a result of higher international oil prices.

The transport component, which has a 14.43 percent weighting in the overall index, eased 0.1 percent in September from August, while the fuel and power component with a 3.26 percent weigthing rose 0.1 percent month-on-month.
"We expect their contribution to CPI to be 0.2-0.3 percent per month while oil prices are rising," Farhan said.
The housing component, which has a 20.54 percent weighting and rose 0.6 percent month-on-month, was a result of some surveys being carried out in that category, Standard Bank said.
Farhan said she did not expect the housing component to increase significantly for the rest of the year as no more interest rate rises were anticipated.
